Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the mother needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Story: It was already a long day when I found myself in the supermarket, my son darting between aisles, giggling as he knocked over a display of cereal boxes. I felt the familiar pressure to teach him right from wrong, to be the mother who calmly but firmly corrects her child, showing him how to behave in public. As I reached for his hand, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was my best friend, calling at this late hour—something must be wrong. I answered, and her sobs filled my ear; she could barely speak, her world unraveling from some terrible news. She needed me to listen, to be present, to offer comfort and support. But my son was still running wild, drawing annoyed glances from other shoppers. I felt torn, my heart pulled in two directions—one part desperate to be the mother my child needed in that moment, the other aching to be the friend my friend needed, right now. I stood there, phone pressed to my ear, my son’s laughter echoing, my friend’s tears heavy in my heart, not knowing which role to choose.
